LeadText.textfield: Language is not just what we say, but how we say it. Scania’s tone of voice is honest, sincere, respectful and confident. Typography is the visualisation of our voice.

section.title: Example Full Width Image Without Caption

section.Title: Introduction
section.Text:
For a strong and unified brand expression, Scania has developed a custom-made and unique font family — Scania Sans. Our typeface has a strong Scania DNA since it derives from our wordmark.

We use typography to present information and structure the entire user interface with clear hierarchy.

section.Title: Functional and Expressive
section.Text:
At Scania, we have divided our typography into two type sets, Functional and Expressive. These two types have different purposes, but there might be applications where a combination of them could be used. 

**Functional**
Should be used in non-branded communication, information and documentation. The main usage is for Scania applications (except apps used in-vehicle), where the typography’s focus is to help the user understand and perform tasks.

**Expressive**
Should be used for more branded external communication and public websites, for instance Scania.com. These types of applications need a much stronger expression for the typography, especially when it comes to headlines.

Learn more about each specific type set:

[Functional type](link)

[Expressive type](link)

**Sub section**
Our brand colours, blue and red, are derived from the Scania symbol and wordmark and effectively establish, represent and communicate the brand. Together with black and white they create our primary palette for digital applications.

LeadText.textfield: At Scania, we use two systems to manage our layout and grid — the Unit and the Grid System. These two systems are the fundament to everything that we design and develop.

section.Title: Unit System
section.Text:
Our base unit is a 4-pixel square. We use multiples of the base unit to create the dimensions of our columns, components and patterns along with their margins and padding to ensure coherency and consistency. Example: 8, 16, 24, 32, 40 px etc.

We do allow the base unit to be divided in 2 when needed, for instance in our spacing scale for elements, due to the size of the elements which demands smaller values.

section.Title: Sizing
section.Text:
To make sure that we create new layouts that are consistent and balanced, we should use our Unit System when sizing content, icons, components and such. See an example of how we use multiples of our base unit when sizing. Note, we have not defined any maximum size. Also, make sure to learn about how we are using our Unit System for Spacing in our elements and layouts.
Pixel Rem
8 2
16 4
24 6
32 8
40 10
48 12
56 14
64 16
72 18
80 20

section.Title: Grid System
section.Text:
A grid system is a structure containing a series of horizontal and vertical lines, used to arrange and present content such as text, imagery and graphics in a structured and well-balanced way. It provides consistency and uniformity of our brand presence and all our page layouts. 

##### Columns
Columns are the foundation of the grid system. The content is placed inside our columns. They are usually too small to contain content by themselves, but when grouped together they create harmonized, coherent and well-crafted design layouts.
 
Our grid system consists of 16 columns for larger screens, 8 for medium and 4 for small screens.  
 
When a browser is in between two breakpoints, the columns scale proportionally (%).

##### Margins
Our margins on each side (left and right) of the grid system are always in a fixed size within the breakpoint. It’s either 24, 16 or 0 px depending on the breakpoint.

##### Padding
Padding is the space inside our columns which we can use to get more space between our content and components. It is possible to select if you want to use the grid system with or without paddings. Grids with gutters rarely need paddings.

Our padding is a defined size of 16 or 8 px depending on breakpoint.

##### Gutters
Gutter is the space between our columns and it aims to help separating content. Our gutter width is a fixed value of 32 px. 

Sometimes a gutterless grid could be a better option when designing for specific applications. When working with a gutterless grid, we automatically get bigger columns within our grid system.

##### Breakpoints Below you will find a defined set of breakpoints, which is available as a grid package at [GitHub](link) and templates in [Figma](link) and [Adobe XD](link).
Breakpoint Width px / rem Columns Size px / % Margin Padding Gutter
$screen-s 320 / 80 4 48 / 15 0 8 px 32 px
$screen-m 672 / 168 8 48 / 7.5 16 px 8 px 32 px
$screen-l 1056 / 264 16 32 / 3.125 16 px 8 px 32 px
$screen-xl 1312 / 328 16 48 / 3.75 16 px 16 px 32 px
$screen-xxl 1584 / 396 16 64 / 4.167 24 px 16 px 32 px

section.Title: Fluid grid
section.Text:
A fluid grid allows the page layout to be adaptive, which means that the content will scale and adapt to the breakpoint size. What’s really happening is that the column size is responsive and continuously growing along with the breakpoint width — even after reaching the max. breakpoint.
 
This approach is mainly used for dashboards or specific editorial content, where it's more important to size up the content rather than slimming the amount of information down.

It is possible to have a fluid grid, both for the default grid system, with and without gutters, and also for the grid push system, which you can find out more about in the next section.

section.Title: Patterns
section.Text:
Within a user interface there are specific sections of the layout where the user expects to find specific information or navigation elements like a header, navigation menu or a cookie bar. This is Patterns, which is a group of components, that should be consistent across devices and breakpoints. They serve a global purpose — to make it easier for users to perform common user objectives and tasks. We have gathered all our [Patterns here](link).

Some of these Patterns  don’t follow the grid system. We have divided these into: floating and fixed patterns. Learn more about the different types below.

##### Floating Pattern: Header
The header is a horizontal element and behaves like a fluid element, which means it should fill the entire browser window width. It doesn’t follow the grid system’s columns and responsiveness — instead it’s placed above the grid system.

##### Fixed Pattern: Left navigation
The left navigation is a vertical element and should fill the entire browser window height. It doesn’t follow the grid systems columns and responsiveness — instead the left navigation acts like a grid push and pushes the grid system to the right and aligns to web browsers left side.

When a left navigation is used, it affects the grid system’s container size, columns, gutters and padding.

LeadText.textfield: Buttons are clickable elements that trigger events or actions. They communicate actions to the users and allow them to interact with pages in a variety of ways.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
Buttons inform the users of possible actions they can take within an application. They can be used throughout different places in your layout, for example: dialogs, modals, forms, cards and toolbars.

The text label is used to inform the user which action that will occur when the user interacts with it.

section.Title: Types
section.Text: There are four types of buttons with different purpose and hierarchy in order to help the user to distinguish the level of importance of the task they represent. These types are primary, secondary, ghost and danger.

Type Usage
Primary High emphasis button used to attract attention to the most important task of the layout. Should be used sparsely within the layout to avoid confusion of which button is the primary action.
Secondary Medium emphasis button used for alternative non-primary actions. Should be used together with a primary button to show a second alternative for a user faced with a choice between two actions.
Ghost Low emphasis button used for less important actions. Usually used in combination with a primary button. Should not be mixed up with or used instead of a link.
Danger Could be used as a final confirmation for a destructive action such as deleting. Mostly used in confirmation modals.

section.Title: States
section.Text: Buttons have different states to communicate the buttons different status for our users.

Images.label: Focused
Images.caption: Highlighted by keyboard or voice
Images.alternate: Focused Highlighted by keyboard or voice

section.Title: Sizes
section.Text: There are four different button sizes: default, medium, small and full bleed where default is our primary button size.

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text:
A button contains at least two elements; a text label, an icon or both in combination with a container. The text label and icon can be used in combination to improve the clarity of the buttons action.

The icon button should only be used for simple and well known actions like download, remove, expand, collapse.

Images.label: Text+icon button
Images.caption:
A. Text label
B. Container
C. Icon

section.Title: Do’s and Dont’s
section.Text:
Below you will find some best practice solutions for buttons.

**Short text labels**

Text labels should be short and direct, since it needs to be easy to read what action the button will perform when the user interacts with it.

**One line text labels**

To secure good legibility, a text label should be placed on one line and not be wrapped on multiple lines. If you have narrowed width space to place your button, move it below the associated content.

**One primary button**

We need to help the user to understand which action is more important by only having one primary button present at the time on the section.

section.Text:

section.Title: Sizing
section.Text:
A button contains at least two elements; a text label, an icon or both in combination with a container. Depending on the button size, the spacing inside the button to its elements varies. When a button is using a text label, the width of the button varies based on text labels length. A full bleed button works differently. Instead of growing with the text labels length, it bleeds to the edges of the component or pattern its placed in.

section.Title: Typography
section.Text:
The text label inside a button should start with the first letter set in upper case, and the remaining letters in lower case. For all of our button types and sizes, we are usign the same typography.

section.Text:
Our button containers have rounded corners with a 4px / 1em corner radius.

LeadText.textfield: The notion of accessibility is about ensuring universal access to a website/application to all its intended users regardless of their disabilities or what software and hardware they use.

section.Title: Overview
section.Text:
Accessibility, in general, refers to the degree of usability of a website/application for users with various kinds of disabilities (e.g. visual, auditory, cognitive etc.). The notion of accessibility was proposed in pursuit of universal access to websites/applications regardless of any disability that a user might have due to their language or location or due to the software and hardware used by them. The objective of accessibility is not to exclude anyone from the use of any website/application that we develop. Accessibility design is considered as an important element of overall user experience of a website/application. W3C (World Wide Web Consortium) has formulated guidelines for accessibility design. Various countries, such as Sweden have also proposed their own accessibility guidelines. In many cases, accessibility of website/application is mandatory by law of the land (e.g. USA). The W3C provides information on the following aspects to help us get started: [1. Guidelines for UI and visual design](https://www.w3.org/WAI/tips/designing/)
[2. Guidelines for development](https://www.w3.org/WAI/tips/developing/) ##### Accessibility Principles In addition to this, the W3C also provides good guidance on the [Principles of Accessibility](https://www.w3.org/WAI/fundamentals/accessibility-principles/). It is recommended that such principles should be followed when designing for accessibility. ##### How do we know a website/application is accessibility compliant? The W3C also provides a guide to carry out checks for accessibility, [see here]( https://www.w3.org/WAI/test-evaluate/preliminary/).

section.Title: Implementing accessibility
section.Text:
The team working with the Scania Digital Design System is committed to the principles of universal accessibility of websites and applications developed at Scania. The principles of accessibility design have been applied for the design of the website of the Scania Digital Design System, which makes it accessibility compliant. 

Moreover, accessibility compliant design elements from the Scania Digital Design System are designed to build accessibility ground up as and when such elements are applied for design and development of Scania website/applications. 

Please reach out to the team should you need any advice on accessibility design and implementation.

LeadText.textfield: Welcome to SDDS, Scania Digital Design System for products and digital experiences! Go through our guide below to get started designing.

section.Title: Install
section.Text:
##### Download the Grid System
Currently the Grid System is only available in Figma. Open Figma and make sure to have the most recent version installed. Then download our Grid System below.

##### Resources
Before opening the UI Kit, make sure you have the latest version of our typeface Scania Sans installed.

##### UI Kit (soon)
During Q1 2020 we will release a UI Kit which will contain all of our components, patters, colours and text styles gathered in one library.

section.Title: Start working
section.Text:
##### Scania Digital Design System Take the time to read and educate yourself about SDDS and its design principles. Make sure that you use our Unit System when designing on your new project. A good start is to go through the documentation to understand how we use that as a fundamental base for our designs for sizing, spacing and positioning. When this is done, you will have the correct foundation to start building new digital solutions for Scania. ##### The Grid System Within the Grid Template file, we have provided a set of breakpoints for the grid system. When starting designing a new project, make sure you copy and paste these breakpoints frames you wish to design for into your new project document. To see the Grid and Units, select your frame and go to:
Menu › View › Layout Grids You can also use the following shortcut to toggle the Grid:
Control + G (MacOs)
Control + Shift + 4 (Windows)

section.Title: Contribute
section.Text:
Scania Digital Design System is an active organism, constantly evolving and adopting to meet the demands of our users. Therefore we strongly encourage and welcome contributions from the whole organisation. Together, we can update and make SDDS a better design system.

Feel free to reach out to us if you want to request a feature or propose a new design.

LeadText.textfield: The SDDS toolbox will help you create an application with Scania look and feel. Here you can find styles and web components that can be used across different frameworks.

section.Title: Scania Theme
section.Text: Scania-theme is a package that contains Scania specific styling for each of those components/patterns in the SDDS toolbox. Every component has a unique styling with Scania look and feel. Moreover, you can also expect to find fonts, icons, tokens and much more.

section.Title: Components
section.Text:
Header, footer or a button are all web components in our design system, the difference between them is how they are technically made. 

```<c-header></c-header>``` is a web component, while a ```<button> Click Me </button>``` is a regular HTML element that already exist in the HTML Standard. One easy thing to differentiate between those is by looking at the dash in the element name, for example "c-header", that indicates it is a webcomponent. 

A web component can be used in the same way as a regular element in the HTML standard. Difference is what is under the hood. You can read more about it [here](developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Web_Components)

All web-components in Scania digital design system have namespace with ```<c-nameOfComponent>```

section.Title: Stencil
section.Text:
To be able to create a component in SDDS, it is essential to have a basic understanding of the tool we are using to make them come to life; a web component compiler called StencilJS. This is the core for our components and how we build them. You can read more in Stencil documentation. StencilJS contains features like: - Virtual DOM - TypeScript - JSX
The following is an example component:

**Loading**
Another very important part with Stencil is how the components are loaded, Stencil is built with self-lazy loading. Only the components that are used (imported) will be loaded into the application and only take that specific space in the memory. You just have to add one import for every component, instead of importing every individual component. The package size of both Scania-theme and Corporate-Ui is something we are always trying to improve.

section.Title: Contribute
section.Text:
If you come across any problems during this installation guide or feel something needs to be more clear, please contact us ou report an issue in our [github](https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system/sdds).

The package size of both Scania-theme and Corporate-Ui is something we are always trying to improve.

LeadText.textfield: There are certain things that need to be in place before a developer can start working with SDDS. A short checklist is presented below.

section.Text: ##### Prerequisites - Node.js 8 and up (Latest stable) - Node packages manager (NPM) for our packages handling - If you are behind firewall, configure proxy - How to install Node you can find in their [documentation](https://nodejs.org/en/download/) and same regarding [NPM (https://www.npmjs.com/get-npm)and [Git](https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Getting-Started-Installing-Git). If you are unfamiliar with NPM and Node, we recommend that you read more about it in their documentation. When Node.js, NPM and Git are installed, you can continue! - Commands to help you see if you have installed these tools:

section.Title: Angular
section.Text: Install SDDS components and Scania-theme in your project, this will install the latest version that is published on npm.

section.code:
> cd <You project folder>
  > npm i @scania-sdds/components
  > npm i @scania-sdds/theme-light

section.Text:
You need to import { addTheme, defineCustomElements } from components package and { theme } from Scania-theme package after you have installed them (See section Installing npm packages).

**Prerequisites**
If you are using Angular 8+, you need to add webcomponents polyfill. Install the dependency:

```npm i @webcomponents/webcomponentsjs --save-dev```

Import the polyfill inside `src/polyfill.ts`

```import '@webcomponents/webcomponentsjs/custom-elements-es5-adapter.js'```

And then, follow the steps below:

section.Title: React
section.Text: Install SDDS components and Scania-theme in your project, this will install the latest version that is published on npm.

section.code:
> cd <You project folder>
  > npm i @scania-sdds/components
  > npm i @scania-sdds/theme-light

section.Title: Vue
section.Text: Install Corporate-UI and Scania-theme in your project, this will install the latest version that is published on npm.

section.code:
> cd <You project folder>
  > npm i corporate-ui
  > npm i scania-theme

section.Text: You need to import { addTheme, defineCustomElements } from Corporate-Ui package and { theme } from Scania-theme package after you haver installed them (See section Installing npm packages).
1. In Vue, go to main.js and import the packages Corporate-Ui and Scania-theme

section.code:
import Vue from 'vue'
 import App from './App.vue'
 //Import Corporate-Ui and Scania-theme
 import { addTheme, defineCustomElements } from 'corporate-ui'
 import { theme } from 'scania-theme'

section.Text: 2. In the main.js you also need to tell the application to ignore custom-element tags such as ```c-header``` by adding this line. Otherwise a warning will be thrown in the console.

section.code:
//Ignore all components custom-elements named c-*
Vue.config.ignoredElements = [/c-\w*/];

section.Text: 3. You need to call defineCustomElements()
4. After that you need to call addTheme() , this function takes one parameter, which is the theme from Scania-theme packages that you imported in step 1.

##### Add theming
When the previous step is done, you can start adding theme to get the styling. Try and add ```c-theme``` component high up in the hierarchy of your application. for example app.js in react. If it works you should see fonts and so on change.

##### Add header,content and footer
After theme is added(Add theming) is done, you can add components ```c-header```,```c-content``` and ```c-footer``` in that order. After that you should see the header and footer. Content component will push down the footer below the content.

content.title: Getting Started Development Creating a component

section.Title: Prerequisites
section.Text:
Prerequisites to create a component

- Git installed
- Github account access

section.Title: Pre-work
section.Text:
##### Clone After you have forked you can start cloning. Go to your cli enviorment and do the following: Clone both repositories from your fork.
##### Corporate-ui ```bash > git clone https://github.com//corporate-ui.git > cd corporate-ui ```
##### Scania-theme ```bash > git clone https://github.com//scania-theme.git > cd scania-theme ```

##### Installing npm packages After the cloning is done, it is time to install all the npm packages. This packages are modules that we are using for different reasons, for example bootstrap, redux and other packages. You can find all our packages in our package.json file. To install our packages you need to be in your project folder, where your package.json file is run *npm install* or *npm i*:
##### Corporate-ui: ```bash > cd corporate-ui > npm install ```
##### Scania theme ```bash > cd scania-theme > npm install ``` **Warnings(warn) might apprear; often, it isn't ,anything causing problems*

##### Building Corporate-UI and Scania-Theme When you are done with install all the npm packages, it is time to build Corporate-ui and Scania-theme. You will do this by running the command *npm run build*. You can find all our commands in package.json file inside *"scripts": { }.*
##### Corporate-ui ```bash > npm run build ``` This will build the components with their functionality without any scania styling. For example the header,footer and so on.
##### Scania theme ```bash > npm run build ``` This will build the styling for every component with scania styling. **Warnings(warn) might apprear, often it isn't anything causing problems*

##### Npm link for Corporate-UI and Scania-Theme When you have built Corporate-UI and Scania-Theme it is time to make is possible to use it locally on your own application. These step might look a bit confusing, but you will need to do this. This will create a symlink with your Corporate-UI and Scania-theme folders instead of using the npm version that you will install. This will make it possible to work locally with corporate-ui and scania-theme. This [linking](https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/link) will create a symlink with your local corporate-ui and scania-theme packages which makes it possible to use those packages. Do the following steps: 1. Install Corporate-UI and Scania-theme in your project, this will install the latest version that is published on npm. ```bash > cd > npm i corporate-ui > npm i scania-theme ```
2. Go to your corporate-ui folder and create a symlink of corporate-ui ```bash > cd corporate-ui > npm link ``` 3. Go to your scania-theme folder and create a symlink of corporate-ui ```bash > cd scania-theme > npm link ``` 4. Go back to your project directory which has corporate-ui and scania-theme installed. This time we will use the `npm link ` command again, but this will create the actual symlink for Corporate-ui and Scania-theme packages in your project. ```bash > cd > npm link corporate-ui > npm link scania-theme ``` After this is done, you will be able to run your local Corporate-Ui and Scania-theme.

LeadText.textfield: Welcome to SDDS, Scania Digital Design System for products and digital experiences!

section.Title: Introduction
section.Text:
The design system supports the design and development of digital solutions at Scania. The purpose is to secure a coherent and premium brand and user experience across all of Scania's digital touchpoints. The main pillars of our Design System are the following: **Foundation**
A resource for principles and styleguide that are considered as the foundations for conceptualization of digital design solutions. **Components**
Our smaller, yet important, interactive building blocks of the design system. These should be used when creating a new digital solution. **Patterns**
Patterns usually consist of multiple components that handle common user objectives and occurring problems. They could be seen as best practices and general solutions for how our users achieves a goal inside our applications. **Resources**
A collection of knowledge assets, tools and downloadable assets to help our designers and developers when creating new digital solutions.

section.Title: Contribute
section.Text:
Scanias Digital Design System is an active organism, constantly evolving and adopting to meet the demands of our users. Therefore we strongly encourage and welcome contributions from the whole organisation. Together, we can update and make SDDS a better design system.

Feel free to reach out to us if you want to request a feature or propose a new design.

linkCards.title: Contribute
linkCards.detail: Functionality is essentially what the website can do and how it works.

linkCards.title: Contribute
linkCards.detail: A new design could be a new component, icon etc. or a change to an existing asset of the design system.

ParagraphRight.textfield:
The design system supports the design and development of digital solutions at Scania. The purpose is to secure a coherent and premium brand and user experience across all of Scania's digital touchpoints.

[Get Started](/getting-started/overview)
Visit our resource section, where we have gathered a library of usable assets for both designing and developing functional and expressive applications.

LeadText.textfield: Scania’s pictogram family helps us to organise and categorise information. Speaking the universal language of symbols, our icons facilitate the encounter with the Scania brand. They create a unified and uncluttered experience in every channel.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
The design of the pictograms — where soft curves meet sharp edges — is inspired by the shapes in our symbol, the Scania Sans typography and our product DNA.

Sometimes the information we need to bring across is detailed, and even complex. Then our illustrative pictograms could be used to visualise information in a simplified way, and when used, supportive text should always be present. 

Correctly used, the pictograms improve the structure and clarity of any message.  We also have [icons](link), which are a smaller non-decorative icon element which purpose is to highlight functions or actions.

section.Title: Sizing
section.Text:
Our pictograms could be used in a variety of sizes, which are based on our Unit System. The minum size is 48px and the maximum size will vary depending on application.

For pictograms in size 48px, we have thicker line width than pictograms larger than 72px. When downloading a pictogram, you will get both a 48 and a 72px version.

Learn more about our [Unit System](link).

section.Title: Resources
section.Text: You can download all our pictograms below. If you are looking for a specific one, please browse our [Pictogram Library](link).

LeadText.textfield: All our pictograms are available in the list below, where you can download or copy the HTML snippet for specific pictograms. Simply browse the list or search to find what you are looking for.

LeadText.textfield: If you need a pictogram, please check thoroughly in our pictogram library if you could use any of the already existing ones. Should the needed pictogram not exist, you may create a new icon following the guidelines below.

section.Title: Re-use elements
section.Text:
Please note that already existing pictogram elements should be re-used as far as possible. As an example for “electricity/power”, the same element (flash) is used in both the battery and the Scania Gensets pictogram. 

Another one is the element “tyre”, which is used both in the pictogram for conditions roads and tyre service.

section.Title: Construct a pictogram
section.Text: Below you find detailed information about how to build a new custom pictogram, using Adobe Illustrator.

Images.label: Step 1 — Grid settings
Images.caption: A square shape pixel grid (256x256px) is used as a base. To match the optical volume sub-containers help to match the different format pictograms.

Images.label: Step 2 — Line width
Images.caption: For the same optical appearance of the pictograms in different sizes, the line width is adjusted. A smaller scale pictogram (up to 48px) requires thicker line width (10 pixels) than a larger one (line width: 7 pixels).

Images.label: Step 3 — Geometry
Images.caption: The pictogram shape is based on the bespoke font Scania Sans, industrial design elements, - a mix of straight lines and curvatures. For letters and numbers in pictograms use the Scania Sans typeface.
The minimum clear space of the pictogram is a square with the same size as 1/8 of the width of the pictogram.

section.Title: Contribution process
section.Text:
##### Approval Before finalising the icon, the icon design including name and description/restrictions, must be approved by any of the central departments Marketing Communications or Brand Management or the Scania Identity Helpdesk at identity@scania.com. ##### File versions and formats Before exporting the icon, make sure to convert all strokes to outlines and unite the icon to one single path. All new icons must always be saved in two versions (positive and negative), two sizes (small and large) and three file formats (.ai, .svg and .png) - in total 12 files for each icon: ##### Positive version: Scania Blue
• PNG and SVG files: RGB 40_30_66
• AI files: CMYK 100_90_13_62 ##### Negative version: Scania White
• PNG and SVG files: RGB 250_250_250
• AI files: CMYK 0_0_0_0 ##### Sizes
• Small: Line width 10px (for sizes 24-48px)
• Large Line width 7px (for sizes 54-72px) ##### Formats
• AI file format for use in print
• PNG and SVG file format for digital use ##### Naming
The icon file name should begin with “ICON”, followed by a short name for the icon and end with the size for which the icon is optimised. For the negative versions “neg” is added after the size. So, the file names for e.g. “Truck service” would then be:
ICON_Truck_service_24-48px.ai /.svg /.png
ICON_Truck_service_24-48px_neg.ai /.svg /.png
ICON_Truck_service_54-72px.ai /.svg /.png
ICON_Truck_service_54-72px_neg.ai /.svg /.png ##### Scania Icon PDF Template
For each new icon a PDF file needs to be created. Use the “Scania Icon PDF Template” and include the following information: • Name of the icon (max. three words)
• Description of the icon
• Restrictions for use of the icon (if any/optional)
• An image/illustration of the new icon The PDF file name should be an ID number (please contact your contact person at the Marketing Communications or Brand Management department or identity@scania.com).

##### Delivery
All icon files are sent together with the PDF file to imagedesk@scania.com (to be published in the “icon library” in Scania Media Provider) and identity@scania.com (to be published in Scania Digital Design System).

Delivering the icon files also means that it is approved to be published as well as archived in Scania Media Provider and Scania Digital Design System. The icon may also be used by other users, for it’s intended purpose and as long as the restrictions (if any) are respected.

##### Support
Should you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact Scania Identity Helpdesk at [identity@scania.com](mailto:identity@scania.com).

section.Title: General
section.Text:
<details>
    <summary>What is Corporate UI?</summary>
    <section>Corporate-UI is framework, based on stencilJS, which provide a UI toolbox to use in your application. All components are Web-components and follow the web-component standard in the browser.</section>
</details>


<details>
  <summary>What is Scania-Theme?</summary>
  <section>Scania-Theme is a package built with CSS(SASS) to style every component according to Scania identity guidelines</section>
</details>


<details>
  <summary>What is a web-component?</summary>
  <section>Web-components are a standard for creating elements that you can use in your application. One standard component that is using the same technology is the <video></video> element. If you look at it with “shadow-dom show” enabled in your settings, you can see it is more than just video elements inside it. One example component in Corporate-UI that is a web-component is the c-header. Web-components consist of:

- Custom-elements
- Shadow DOM
- HTML templates

You can read more about it here: [Link](https://auth0.com/blog/creating-web-components-with-stencil/)</section>
</details>


<details>
    <summary>Is there any documentation or list of components?</summary>
    <section>

You can find documentation of components here: [Link](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/components)
</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>Where do I find the Experimental components and patterns?</summary>
    <section>

We are planning to add all experimental components and pattern into Scania Digital Design System site later. Right now it is not possible to see component that is under development. You can check [corporate-ui repository](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui) to see our current backlog and components that are being developed in the moment.</section>
</details>


<details>
  <summary>What should I do if I find a component that isn’t accessible?</summary>
  <section>Contact our team</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>Where can I get help implementing the components with my project?</summary>
  <section>

Read how to use components in the [getting started section](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/getting-started/development) </section>
</details>

<details>

  <summary>Why is Corporate-UI / Scania-Theme so big?</summary>
  <section>

   A very important part with Stencil is how the components are loaded, Stencil is built with [self-lazy loading](https://stenciljs.com/docs/distribution).

   Only the components that are used(imported) will be loaded into the application and only take that specific space in the memory.

   You just have to add one import for every component, instead of importing every individual component. The package size of both Scania-theme and Corporate-Ui is something are always trying to improve.

 </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>Is there Dark mode in Corporate-UI? </summary>
    <section>Right now, no. But this is something that is highly demanded. The reason why we haven’t added is that it needs a lot for research before something like that can be implemented</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>I need a new icon, how do I add it?</summary>
    <section>

- First, check if icon is available [here](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/foundation/icons)
- Icon that has been included in Scania Media Provider but not available in Corporate UI: Create a [feature request](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/issues/new/choose) with detail information about the icon that you need.
- New icon: Contact our team for more information.

</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>Are there .psd or .sketch files of the components?</summary>
    <section>

[Link](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/resources/ui-kits)</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>Can I use custom bootstrap javascript plugin such as modal, tooltip, carousel together with Corporate-ui? </summary>
    <section>
      Yes.  We have bootstrap plugin script built in Corporate UI. You can access them by enabling global attribute in c-theme component.

<c-theme name='scania' global='true'></c-theme>

It is important to listen to 'bsReady' event before initiating bootstrap plugin. An example how to use it:

document.addEventListener('bsReady', function(event) {
CorporateUi.$('#modalMoveSelected').modal('hide')
});</section>

</details>

section.Title: What is supported
section.Text:
<details>
  <summary>Who can use the components?</summary>
  <section>Developers, with somewhat understanding of front-end development for all web based application</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>Which browsers are supported?</summary>
  <section>All Major ones. IE, Chrome FF and Edge, with polyfills if needed</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>What JavaScript frameworks are supported?</summary>
  <section>Angular, React and Vue. More might come in the future.

[See live examples](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/resources/development).
</section>
</details>


<details>
  <summary>Can I use corporate-ui on third party application?</summary>
  <section>Third part application is very limited support, due to every third-party application is built differently. If you know you can import libraries and so on, please try it out!</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>Why did you stop supporting font-awesome pro? </summary>
  <section>We took the decision to start creating and using our own Scania icons. You can still use font-awesome pro, but you need to buy your own licence.</section>
</details>

section.Title: Migration
section.Text:
<details>
  <summary>Is it possible to migrate from Corporate-ui 3 to 4?</summary>
  <section>

Yes, it is! It will take some effort, but that is how all upgrades are when it is a major one. You can read more about it in our migration guide ([Link](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/getting-started/development)). One thing to remember is that, not everything that was in Corporate-UI 3 will be in 4. We have removed and/or changed some components and dependencies that we had, for example upgrade bootstrap 3 to 4.

</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>What are the differences between version three and version four?</summary>
    <section>
      One of the key things that changed are:

- Moved from polymer to stencilJS
- Upgrade from Bootstrap 3 to 4
- How you import a component
- Scania-theme is added for styling components
- Removed Font-awesome Pro support
- Not using BootstrapNativeJS for JS support in bootstrap

[Read migration guideline here](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/getting-started/development)
    </section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>What are the major changes Bootstrap 3 to 4?</summary>
  <section>

You can see what are the major changes in bootstrap 3 to 4 in bootstraps own documentation. For example Panel component have been removed and replaced by cards. [Link](https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.4/migration/)
</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>I haven’t updated to the latest version of Corporate UI yet, and I still need the old documentation. Where can I find it?</summary>
    <section>

[Visit documentation for Corporate UI 3](https://scania.github.io/corporate-ui-docs/)
</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>Will you add every component that bootstrap 4 have?</summary>
  <section>We will add component that has been requested and had a good reason to be added in.</section>
</details>

section.Title: Contribution
section.Text:
<details>
    <summary>How do I modify a components styling, structure or functionality ? </summary>
    <section>Depending what part of the components you want to modify:

- Styling: Corporate-UI for base component and Scania-theme
- Structure: Corporate-UI
- Functionality: Corporate-UI

</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>I need a new component, who do I talk to? </summary>
  <section>

Corporate UI is an open source and collaborative project. It means you can develop your own component and make a pull-request to add it as a part of Corporate UI. [See contributing guidelines here]( https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).
If you cannot make your own component, you can add a feature request in our Github page : [Link to Github](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/issues/new/choose) or contact our team</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>How do I make a pull request? What branch should I pull request into?</summary>
  <section>

[Read contribution guideline](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)</section>
</details>

section.Title: Debug
section.Text:
<details>
  <summary>How do I debug? </summary>
  <section>

- Investigate the cause of your problem from the development window. Go to the browser, and press *Ctr+Shift+I*. Check console tab, and see the error message.
- Version: First of you need to know which version you are using, maybe the problem is solved in later version. Look at the HTML TAG
- Styling/CSS/SASS problem: Look if anything is overriding our/your css first depending what you except.
- Crashing: If there is any error what files is it coming from? Try and investigate, remove Corporate-UI/Scania-theme dependencies see if the error still occurs or maybe upgrade?
- If you still can’t see the solution either report in [Github](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/issues/new/choose) or ask in [team channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/team/19%3a1257007a64d44c64954acca27a9d4b46%40thread.skype/conversations?groupId=79f9bfeb-73e2-424d-9477-b236191ece5e&tenantId=3bc062e4-ac9d-4c17-b4dd-3aad637ff1ac) for support

</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>How do I see which version of Corporate-UI I’m using?</summary>
    <section>

You can see that in the HTML tag , NPM package you installed and in the script if you are using CDN.
![Corporate UI version](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/4607f69014b24c45bd78c4b4f053b8ed.png)
</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>I see a bug. How do I report it?</summary>
  <section>

You can report in [Github](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/issues/new/choose)</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>What can I expect for a response to my bug report?</summary>
  <section>

Our team will try to help fix the bug as soon as possible depends on the severity of the bug. If you know the solution, you can contribute and add the solution to corporate-ui by creating a pull-request. Please provide a detail information or an idea for the solution when you report an issue. This will make the the bug can be solved faster.  [Read contribution guideline](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).</section>
</details>

##### Introduction

Below is our most frequently asked questions and their answers about the Scania Digital Design System in general. FAQs address both [design](support/faqs/design) and [development](support/faqs/development) related questions (and answers) which are organised in separate sections. 

The FAQ section is updated on an ongoing basis, so please reach out to us if you have questions that you think should be included here.

<details>
    <summary>Is Scania Digital Design System accessible outside the Scania network?</summary>
    <section>Yes. 
</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>Is Scania Digital Design System available on mobile platform?</summary>
    <section>Not at the moment. But we are working on it and we will make it available on mobile platforms in near future.</section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>Who works on the Scania Digital Design System?</summary>
    <section>The Corporate Digital Design team (IXCD) works as the owners of Scania Digital Design System. The team collaborates with various teams across Scania as and when required.
    </section>
</details>

<details>
    <summary>I want to modify look and feel of a UI element. Is it possible?</summary>
    <section>Yes, it is possible but the modified UI element requires approval from the Scania Digital Design System governance team. There is a process in place for this purpose. For further information, please get in touch with Marcus Åstrom directly.
    </section>
</details>

    <summary>How do I see which version of Corporate-UI I’m using?</summary>
    <section>

You can see that in the HTML tag , NPM package you installed and in the script if you are using CDN.
![Corporate UI version](https://sdds-cms.s3.amazonaws.com/4607f69014b24c45bd78c4b4f053b8ed.png)
</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>I see a bug. How do I report it?</summary>
  <section>

You can report in [Github](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/issues/new/choose)</section>
</details>

<details>
  <summary>What can I expect for a response to my bug report?</summary>
  <section>

Our team will try to help fix the bug as soon as possible depends on the severity of the bug. If you know the solution, you can contribute and add the solution to corporate-ui by creating a pull-request. Please provide a detail information or an idea for the solution when you report an issue. This will make the the bug can be solved faster.  [Read contribution guideline](https://github.com/scania/corporate-ui/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).</section>
</details>

##### Do you need help within development?
Please start by browsing the FAQ to see if there´s already an answer to your question. If not, please reach out to us in Teams or GitHub.

##### Need help within design?
Please browse the FAQ  to see if there’s already an answer to your question. If not please get in touch with us through Teams and we'll do our best to help out.

##### Do you think something is missing that should be there?
If you have an idea for addtion of a design pattern, component or a feature or more that you think should be included in the design system, please tell use via the contribution section. Your contribution will then be reviewed and taken into consideration for SDDS.

LeadText.textfield: The Scania design system welcomes contributions from the  whole organisation. Together, we can grow Scania design system and make it a better framework.

section.Title: Information
section.Text: Because Scania design system provides everything from the abstract patterns of a design system to the nitty-gritty implementation of accessibility for components, contributions to Scania design system can take many forms, and each of them will correspond to part of the full process.

    <section>Not at the moment. But we are working on it and we will make it available on mobile platforms in near future.</section>

<details>
    <summary>Who works on the Scania Digital Design System?</summary>
    <section>The Corporate Digital Design team (IXCD) works as the owners of Scania Digital Design System. The team collaborates with various teams across Scania as and when required.

<details>

    <section>Yes, it is possible but the modified UI element requires approval from the Scania Digital Design System governance team. There is a process in place for this purpose. For further information, please get in touch with Marcus Åstrom directly.
    </section>
</details>

LeadText.textfield: We are still working on this page. It will be out by Q1 2021.
Language is not just what we say, but how we say it. Scania’s tone of voice is honest, sincere, respectful and confident. Typography is the visualisation of our voice.

section.Title: Introduction
section.Text:
For a strong and unified brand expression, Scania has developed a custom-made and unique font family — Scania Sans. Our typeface has a strong Scania DNA since it derives from our wordmark.

We use typography to present information and structure the entire user interface with clear hierarchy.

section.Title: Functional & Expressive
section.Text:
At Scania, we have divided our typography into two type sets, Functional and Expressive. These two types have different purposes, but there might be applications where a combination of them could be used. **Functional** Should be used in non-branded communication, information and documentation. The main usage is for Scania applications (except apps used in-vehicle), where the typography’s focus is to help the user understand and perform tasks. **Expressive** Should be used for more branded external communication and public websites, for instance Scania.com. These types of applications need a much stronger expression for the typography, especially when it comes to headlines. Learn more about each specific type set:
[Functional type](foundation/foundation-typography/functional-type) [Expressive type](foundation/foundation-typography/expressive-type)

section.Title: Typeface
section.Text:
The Scania Sans typeface family has several fonts and weights, making it ideal for every context and every occasion, from bold and inspiring headlines to informative footnotes.. The typeface family has four fonts:
— Scania Sans Headline
— Scania Sans
— Scania Sans Semi Condensed
— Scania Sans Condensed

section.Title: Type settings
section.Text:
We use four type settings when applying typography within our user interfaces. These type settings have several text styles that could be found at [Functional type](foundation/foundation-typography/functional-type) and [Expressive type](foundation/foundation-typography/expressive-type).

**Headline**
Used to create clear typographic hierarchies.

**Paragraph**
Use for introduction texts.

**Body**
Used primarily for longer body texts, intro texts and specific components. 

**Detail**
Used for captions, detailed text, table, component and code related typography.

section.Title: Type scale
section.Text:
When designing and creating new layouts and applications, you should use any of our defined type sets Functional or Expressive, depending on what you’re designing for. This scale will help you create consistent layouts with a balanced rhythm. In some specific scenarios, you might end up needing a size that is not specified within those type sets. When adding a new text style, you should select a size from our type scale below to get a cohesive typographic experience.
Rem Pixel Example
2.5 10 Scania Sans Regular
3 12 Scania Sans Regular

18 72 Scania Sans Regular
20 80 Scania Sans Regular

section.Title: Tokens
section.Text:
For managing our typography, we use tokens that have defined all our typographic settings such as font size, font weight, letter height and letter spacing. These tokens should be used when designing a new page layout or application.

Visit [Functional type](foundation/foundation-typography/functional-type) and [Expressive type](foundation/foundation-typography/expressive-type) to get a full overview of which tokens that are available within each type set.

section.Title: Fallback
section.Text:
When Scania Sans fail to load due to technical issues or when technical restrictions or special glyphs for languages limits the use of Scania Sans typeface, the following replacement fonts – or similar - are recommended:

**Mac computers**
Helvetica Neue

**PC computers**
Arial

section.Title: Installation
section.Text: You can install SDDS typography package with [npm](https://www.npmjs.com/). Run the following command:

section.Title: Usage

LeadText.textfield: Below you will find a comprehensive list of useful Scania Manuals and Guidelines.

section.Text:
##### Scania Identity Manual

The Scania brand identity has been designed to unite and modernise the brand expression and to support the desired brand image. Our visual identity is defined in the Scania Identity Manual and needs to be used by following the defined rules within this document.

##### Mobile Application Styleguide (Appendix)

To ensure a strong unified global brand identity and experience, principles for applying the Scania brand assets in mobile applications have been developed. This appendix is part of the Scania Identity Manual.

LeadText.textfield: The logotype is an important graphic identifier. It creates brand recognition in all our applications, but also recognition and coherence across different digital applications.

section.Title: Resources
section.Text:
Our logotype is one of our primary assets, our strongest branding tools which can be used across all channels at all times. More information about the logotype and other brand assets is available in the [Scania Identity manual](resources/brand/manuals). 

The logotype consists of 3 different versions.

**Wordmark**
Unique and distinct, the wordmark – Scania – is the most direct and effective asset in communicating the brand. It’s used in the header and may also be repeated in the footer, but never in body text. 

**Symbol**
The symbol with the eye-catching griffin at the centre, conveys quality and robustness and is always placed in the header. 

**Lock-up logotype**
Our wordmark and symbol together form a lock-up logotype. It’s a fixed asset, available in a vertical and horizontal version.

More detailed information about how the logotype versions are used and placed will be available in the patterns section (header and footer) in Q1.

LeadText.textfield: Language is not just what we say, but how we say it. Scania’s tone of voice is honest, sincere, respectful and confident. Typography is the visualisation of our voice.

section.Text:
#### Scania Sans

To retain and represent our unique voice in every communication channel, we have our own font family — Scania Sans. Our typeface has a strong Scania DNA since it derives from our wordmark.

We use typography to present our information content and the entire user interface with clear hierarchy.

LeadText.textfield: Images and films are efficient tools for telling our stories at Scania, to provide useful information and to create more inspirational and rich experiences.

section.Text:
##### Resources
At Scania Media Provider, you will get access to an extensive image and film archive. Visit the website, log in with your Scania/XDS account and start browsing for the imagery that you need.

LeadText.textfield: Scania’s pictogram family helps us to organise and categorise information. Speaking the universal language of symbols, our icons facilitate the encounter with the Scania brand. They create a unified and uncluttered experience in every channel.

section.Text:
#### Resources

You can download all our pictograms below. If you are looking for a specific one, please browse our [Pictogram Library](link). If you need a pictogram, please check thoroughly in our pictogram library if you could use any of the already existing ones. Should the needed pictogram not exist, you may create a new icon following our [guidelines](link).

LeadText.textfield:
The UI Kit will contain all of our components, patterns and resources that you need to start building a new digital Scania application.

Currently, the UI Kit is work in progress. It will be available to download here in Q1.
At Scania, we use two systems to manage our layout and grid — the Unit and the Grid System. These two systems are the fundament to everything that we design and develop.

section.Text:
#### Install
##### Download the Grid System
Currently the Grid System is only available in Figma. Open Figma and make sure to have the most recent version installed. Then download our Grid System below.

##### Resources
Before opening the UI Kit, make sure you have the latest version of our typeface [Scania Sans](foundation/foundation-typography) router installed.

LeadText.textfield: At Scania, we have two levels of working in design.

section.Text:
##### 1. Way of working between the UX design team and the Agile development team

It is recommended that UX design stage precedes Agile development stage. In practice, the UX design stage is recommended to be carried out at two levels. One, at meta level where the information architecture (IA) of the solution is carried out and finalized in collaboration with the development team. At the same time, this stage of UX design also delivers detailed wireframes, including the behaviour of the interactive elements, that are evaluated with the intended users. Once this is finalised, it provides the vision for the development team. 

The development team then breaks down the vision in terms of epics, stories and sub tasks and prioritize them for development. Two, at micro level, where UX design team details out the wireframes – for the epic/story prioritised for development - and provides UI specifications for development. This stage of UX design works in parallel with development and provides continuous contribution as required by the epic/story. Once an epic/story is implemented and tested, the UX design team, moves on to the next sprint/development stage and repeats above mentioned tasks based on the epic/story. This continues until the end of the project.

##### 2. The way of working within the UX team

UX team is, ideally, a multidisciplinary team with its members coming from a variety of disciplines, such as, design, computer science, graphic design, psychology, anthropology, sociology etc. It is not always the case that the UX design team will have this kind of diversity. At the same time, it is common for UX designers (through their education and experience) to have a good level of competence (originating from a variety of fields, such as sociology, design etc.) to run all aspects of the UX design process.

Given this, the UX design team should assess their competencies via a vis UX various stages of UX design process (such as, research, design, prototyping and evaluation) and assign responsibilities of conducting each such stages amongst themselves.

The UX design process, then, is carried out iteratively, in a sprint like fashion. That is, when the first cycle of UX design process constituting of research, design, prototyping and evaluation is complete and reflected upon (to access if the solution arrived at meets the needs of the intended users), another cycle of UX design process is carried out and the same is repeated until the solution arrived at addresses the needs of the intended users in the best possible manner and at an optimum cost.

Image.label: Scania UX Phases
Image.caption: Detailed roadmap of the UX work phases

LeadText.textfield: This section offers a number of resources for designers, developers and others who might be interested in the process of design and development of digital design solutions at Scania.

It offers high level resources, such as definitions and way of working for design and development teams, as well as downloadable resources, such as UI design kit and various resources for development.

LeadText.textfield: A divider is a 1px line that help us group and separate content within our layouts, components and patterns.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
Dividers help us both to group and to separate content. We use dividers within our page layouts and also within our components and patterns.

They should be used sparingly and only if we can’t separate content using white space. Too many dividers present on a small surface will be perceived as a cluttered and busy experience.

section.Title: Types
section.Text:
We have two different types of dividers, full-bleed dividers and indent dividers. Each type has a horizontal and vertical version.

##### Full-bleed dividers
Full-bleed dividers are as the name describes, full-bleed components. This means that a full-bleed divider is aligned with the margins of the component or the page.

This type of dividers is used to separate different sections within a layout, to separate unrelated texts inside lists (for instance a data table) and to separate content inside a header for instance.

##### Indent dividers

The opposite to full-bleed dividers is our indent dividers. They have the same visual appearance and what separates them is that these do not behave as a full-bleed component. Indent dividers are used to separate related content, inside lists or data tables for instance.

Images.label: Indent divider
Images.caption: Vertical example used in a sub headline

section.Title: Colour
section.Text:
Dividers come in different colours. Depending on what theme or background colour the divider exists on, the colour of the divider varies.

On our lightest backgrounds, the colour of the divider will be the next step above the background colour. For instance, $white background equals $grey-100 divider and $grey-100 background equals $grey-200 divider. 

On background colours with 300 or higher, colour of the divider will be the next step below the background colour. For instance, $grey-300 background equals $grey-200 divider.

The exception is when we reach the highest step within a colour, 900. Then we will use 700 as divider colour to make sure that we have a good contrast between the divider and the background.

##### Examples
Background Divider colour
$white $grey-100
$grey-100 $grey-200
$grey-200 $grey-300
$grey-300 $grey-200
$grey-400 $grey-300
$grey-500 $grey-400
$grey-600 $grey-500
$grey-700 $grey-600
$grey-800 $grey-700
$grey-900 $grey-700

section.Title: Specs
section.Text: Our dividers, both full-bleed and indents, have a width of 1 px / 0.25 rem.

LeadText.textfield: We are still working on this page. It will be out by Q1 2021.
A text field is a component that facilitates entry and editing of text. In general text fields are used to collect and post subsequently information provided by users.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text: Text fields are used as an integral part of a form (of various kinds) to enable users to edit and post text. Text fields should be legible so that users know where to enter the text. In addition to this, text fields should clearly show its state to convey when text can or cannot be entered.

section.Title: Types
section.Text:
Text fields have two different types; label inside and label outside.

You should select text field type based on which context the text field will be placed in and what works best with the applications design you are working with in general. 

For instance, the type label inside works well for more narrow spaces and label outside is a good option for forms with a lot of text fields present, making it easier for the users to decode the information.

section.Title: Sizes
section.Text: There are two different text field sizes: default and medium where default is our primary text field size. Medium could be a good option to use for more narrow spaces. As for types, size could also be selected depending on what works best with the applications design you are working with.

Images.label: Default
Images.caption: Use as primary text field size

section.Title: States
section.Text: Text fields have different states to communicate the fields’ different status for our users.

Images.label: Focused
Images.caption: Highlighted by keyboard, voice or mouse

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text: A text field contains at least 3 elements; a text label and a container plus input text, when the user have input text.

Images.label: Label inside
Images.caption:
- A. Container
- B. Prefix icon/text (optional)
- C. Label text
- D. Input text
- E. Suffix icon/text (optional)
- F. Helper text (optional)

section.Text:
**Container**

Containers are the base of the text field, and it is a filled container with a bottom-border. The container has top rounded corners and square bottom corners. The bottom-border varies in height and colour depending on the state to emphasize this.

**Label text**

Label text is the text that communicates to the user what text information that should be submitted inside each text field.

**Input text**

Input text is the text that has been submitted by a user.

**Prefix and Suffix icons**

The prefix and suffix icons are optional. Prefix icons could be used to communicate to the user the valid input method and suffix icons are mainly used as actions, such as clear text or reveal a date picker. They could also be used to indicate another text format within the text field, such as password input or to highlight invalid text input.

**Prefix and Suffix text**

Prefix and suffix text are optional. They could be used to communicate a specific measurement unit, currency and such.

**Helper text**

Helper text assists the user with additional information text on how it will be used, display the maximum amount of characters limit or to describe an invald text input.

Images.label: Character counter
Images.caption: Used if there is a character limit

section.Text:
**Placeholder text**

Another way to assist users is to use a placeholder text, which hints of what type of information that should be entered. The placeholder text disappears when the user starts typing inside the text field.

**Input types**

There are two input types for how our text fields can display user input; single line or text areas.

Single line is used when the user should enter a single line text. Text areas should be used for input text with more than one sentence which requires multiple lines.

section.Title: Do’s and Don’ts
section.Text:
Below you will find some best practice solutions for text fields.

**Short label text**

The label text should be short and direct and not be complex nor placed on multiple lines.

**Use one text field style**

The text field style should be the same within one section or form.

Spacing is just as important as the Unit and Grid System. It helps us to create a harmonious layout, with both vertical and horizontal rhythm.

section.Title: Introduction
section.Text:
By having clear spacing scales, we limit the layout to make use of only a specific number of units instead of using a wide span of various spacing options which quickly escalates and creates an inconsistent experience. We also make sure that we are consistent across our entire components library.

At Scania, we use two spacing scales which both are based on our Unit System; layout scale and element scale. Both the scales are applicable on vertical and horizontal edges.

section.Title: Layout scale
section.Text:
The layout scale is used when we position content, components and patterns on a page layout. This scale should always be used when creating new layouts. 

Should an application need an additional spacing size, make sure to use our Unit System as base to create a consistent spacing scale when creating a new token.

Rem Pixel Token Scale
2 8 $spacing-layout-8
4 16 $spacing-layout-16
6 24 $spacing-layout-24
8 32 $spacing-layout-32
12 48 $spacing-layout-48
16 64 $spacing-layout-64
24 96 $spacing-layout-96
32 128 $spacing-layout-128
40 160 $spacing-layout-160

section.Title: Element scale
section.Text:
The element scale is used when building components where we need smaller units to work with, when defining all detailed work within a component. Should a component need an additional spacing size, make sure to use our Unit System as base to create a consistent spacing scale, when creating a new token.
Rem Pixel Token Scale
0.5 2 $spacing-layout-2

10 40 $spacing-layout-40
12 48 $spacing-element-48

section.Title: Exceptions
section.Text:
There are exceptions within Scania user interfaces where we don’t use our spacing element token for spacing elements.

**Centre**
This is used when we contextually need to centre an element between two edges, for instance a text within a specific button component.

Without using words, colours tell the story of a brand. Colours convey an immediate and lasting impression, which is why the brand colour palette is of crucial importance.

section.Title: Colour
section.Text: Our colour palette for digital platforms consists of primary and secondary colours, which derives from our colours defined in our brand identity. We also have an extended palette that consists of a range of scales, which carefully and purposefully should be used as supporting colours and a number of semantic colours used strictly for UI CTAs and notifications such as alarm, warning, success and information.

**Primary palette**
Our brand colours, blue and red, are derived from the Scania symbol and wordmark and effectively establish, represent and communicate the brand. Together with black and white they create our primary palette for digital applications.

##### Secondary palette
Our secondary palette is designed to be used to vary or highlight content. These colours add warmth and variety in our layouts, along with associations to sustainability and our well-grounded company. This palette is mainly used for our Expressive experiences, where we need a more dynamic and rich colour palette.

##### Semantic colours
The purpose of our semantic colours is to quickly and efficiently signal a specific CTA or information to the user. The colours are used to create clear communication hierarchies within our applications and should be used with care and purpose. Never use these colours as decoration or as a background colour on large surfaces.

When using these colours, they need to be paired with text, an icon or both to fulfil their purpose in the best way possible.

section.Title: Scales
section.Text:
As supporting colours to our primary, secondary and semantic colours, we have several steps for each colour, creating a scale. Instead of creating new colours, we can use these steps to drive brand recognition and create strong associations to the brand. These scales enables us to create strong and clear colour hierarchies within our applications. 

Some of the steps are used as background colours, others on text, icons, CTAs or dividers. The most prominent ones are the Grey and Blue colour scales, while the others are used more sparingly. 

The scales do not only have to be applied within our applications - they could also be used in visualisations and illustrations to ensure a unified overall brand presence.

Image.caption: All scales are available at Specifications

section.Title: Themes
section.Text:
For all Scania applications we have two themes, light and dark theme. These themes serve as foundation for colours. Depending on what and for whom you are designing, you should select which theme to use carefully.

Light theme
This theme is the standard choice for Expressive applications, where we need to have a dynamic and rich brand experience. It’s also the standard choice for our Functional applications, where the user is mainly active in a work place with natural lightning.

Dark theme
The dark theme is a low-light UI which uses our darker colours as primary background colours. In general we use more desaturated colours since colours with high saturation tend to vibrate on dark backgrounds. 

A dark framework helps to reduce eye-strain for our users, especially when they are using our applications during night time or in a low-light environment in general. It also has a sustainable approach, since it conserves battery life for devices with OLED screens.  This theme is mainly used for our Functional applications.

Another option is to apply a toggle within your application, to let the users own personal preference decide which theme to use.

section.Title: Legibility
section.Text:
At Scania we value accessibility and consider it as an important element of an overall user experience within our applications. Our texts and links should be legible and meet [The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG 2.0) level AA](link), which requires a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 for normal text, and 3:1 to large text.

Our colours have a scale which consists of 10 values (black and white excluded). On backgrounds using darker values, white text is accessible and on backgrounds using lighter values, dark text is accessible.

Learn more about our thoughts on [Accessibility design](link).

section.Title: Colour tokens
section.Text:
In our Unit System, we are using tokens to manage our variables, and this is to be able to go away from having hard coded values to ensure consistency in our UIs. It also makes it more efficient to implement, maintain and update.

We are using the same approach for our colour palettes. For instance, instead of coding all instances when using our blue colour with #041E42, we can instead apply a token like $blue-900.

Below you find detailed lists of all of Scanias colours. Note, these are also available at [Github](link).

section.Title: Usage

LeadText.textfield: Below you will find a comprehensive list of useful Scania Manuals and Guidelines.

section.Text:
##### Scania Identity Manual

The Scania brand identity has been designed to unite and modernise the brand expression and to support the desired brand image. Our visual identity is defined in the Scania Identity Manual and needs to be used by following the defined rules within this document.

##### Mobile Application Styleguide (Appendix)

To ensure a strong unified global brand identity and experience, principles for applying the Scania brand assets in mobile applications have been developed. This appendix is part of the Scania Identity Manual.

LeadText.textfield: Language is not just what we say, but how we say it. Scania’s tone of voice is honest, sincere, respectful and confident. Typography is the visualisation of our voice.

section.Text:
#### Scania Sans

To retain and represent our unique voice in every communication channel, we have our own font family — Scania Sans. Our typeface has a strong Scania DNA since it derives from our wordmark.

We use typography to present our information content and the entire user interface with clear hierarchy.

LeadText.textfield: Scania’s pictogram family helps us to organise and categorise information. Speaking the universal language of symbols, our icons facilitate the encounter with the Scania brand. They create a unified and uncluttered experience in every channel.

section.Text:
#### Resources

You can download all our pictograms below. If you are looking for a specific one, please browse our [Pictogram Library](link). If you need a pictogram, please check thoroughly in our pictogram library if you could use any of the already existing ones. Should the needed pictogram not exist, you may create a new icon following our [guidelines](link).

LeadText.textfield: Images and films are efficient tools for telling our stories at Scania, to provide useful information and to create more inspirational and rich experiences.

section.Text:
##### Resources
At Scania Media Provider, you will get access to an extensive image and film archive. Visit the website, log in with your Scania/XDS account and start browsing for the imagery that you need.
